Natalie DiBlasio, USA TODAY

Severe weather could snarl holiday travel Wednesday

Blizzard warnings stretch from Arkansas to Illinois

Major airlines are waiving re-booking fees for fliers

Returning Wednesday from Christmas celebrations could be a tough, slippery or delayed ride for travelers in many parts of the country.

A major winter storm carrying snow, sleet and freezing rain was forecast to move across the Midwest overnight and continue into the upper Midwest, Upstate New York and parts of New England on Wednesday, according to AccuWeather.

The storms were blamed for three deaths, and a Christmas Day twister outbreak left damage across the Deep South. More than 100,000 customers were without power in Texas, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Mississippi, Louisiana and Alabama.

In Mobile, Ala., a tornado or high winds damaged homes and knocked down power lines and large tree limbs in an area just west of downtown around nightfall, said Nancy Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Mobile County Commission.

The forecasting service says, tornadoes, thunderstorms and damaging winds that struck Tuesday along the Gulf Coast will move into the Carolinas and into parts of Georgia and Florida on Wednesday.

The bad weather threatens to snarl traffic on highways in the Midwest and Northeast and lead to major flight delays and cancellations on one of the heaviest travel days of the year.

"Travel is going to get rough," says Marshall Moss, vice president of forecasting at AccuWeather.

A blizzard warning late Tuesday stretched across northeastern Arkansas, southeastern Missouri, southwestern Indiana, western Kentucky and southern Illinois amid predictions of 6 to 12 inches of snow by Wednesday morning, says Marshall Moss, vice president of forecasting at AccuWeather.

Some areas of Arkansas' Ozark Mountains could get up to 12 inches of snow, making travel "very hazardous or impossible" in the northern tier of the state from near-whiteout conditions, the National Weather Service says.

Snow and ice pose dangers for many of the 84.4 million people that auto club AAA estimated hit the road for Christmas holiday trips of at least 50 miles.

It won't be much better for many air travelers seeking to get home.

"It will be a horrific day for travel in Buffalo, Cleveland, Detroit, Indianapolis and Pittsburgh," AccuWeather meteorologist Mark Paquette warns.

"There will be major problems, major delays for airports."

Major airlines, including US Airways, Delta, American Airlines and Southwest Airlines, told passengers late Tuesday they could rebook their flights over the next couple of days without having to pay a penalty fee.

Airlines had estimated that 42 million passengers would be flying this Christmas and New Year's holiday.

The strange mix of winter weather – tornadoes, snow, freezing rain and high winds – began making havoc early on Christmas Day.

More than 360 flights nationwide were canceled and more than 2,970 delayed as of 4:30 p.m. Tuesday, according to the flight tracker FlightStats.com. Most were out of the Dallas-Fort Worth airport.

Icy roads already were blamed for a 21-vehicle pileup in Oklahoma, and the Highway Patrol said a 28-year-old woman was killed in a crash on a snowy U.S. highway near Fairview. In New Mexico, drivers across the eastern Plains had to fight through snow, ice and low visibility.

At least three tornadoes were confirmed in Texas. The Harris County Sheriff's Office near Houston said a 25-year-old man died after strong storms knocked a tree onto his pickup.

A 53-year-old north Louisiana man was killed when a tree fell on his house.



"You don't want to mess around with tornadoes," Paquette says. "Anytime you have a storm that is creating tornadoes and snow at the same time is a big deal."

search_result.title: Thousands of flights delayed as weather wreaks havoc on holiday ...
search_result.text:
Americans scrambled to get home after a swath of bad weather helped force thousands of flight delays over the Thanksgiving holiday weekend and storms forecast for Tuesday threatened more travel chaos.

More than 4,500 flights within, into, or out of the U.S. were delayed or canceled by Monday night – this after almost 7,000 flights were delayed Sunday, one of the year's busiest travel days, according to the tracking website flightaware.com.

Travel is back in a big way after the crushing effects of COVID-19. AAA estimated that 54.6 million people were traveling 50 miles or more from home over the Thanksgiving weekend. That’s a 1.5% increase over 2021 – and 98% of pre-pandemic levels.

This year was projected to be the third busiest for Thanksgiving travel since AAA started tracking in 2000. But heavy rains and thunderstorms in the South and snow in the Pacific Northwest helped fuel some post-Thanksgiving travel problems. And the hazardous weather is far from over.

30 million at risk for severe weather

A storm rolling out of the Rockies was forecast to bring severe weather ranging from high winds to tornadoes from Illinois and Indiana to Texas. AccuWeather meteorologists warned that about 30 million people in the south-central United States will be at risk for severe thunderstorms on Tuesday alone. Wind gusts from the storms will frequently reach 60 to 70 mph, and 85 mph is possible, AccuWeather said.

"We are fairly confident that there will be multiple tornadoes on the ground," AccuWeather Chief On-Air Meteorologist Bernie Rayno said. "People should take this threat seriously."

The National Weather Service blamed a strong cold front tracking across the Intermountain West on Monday with strong winds, heavy snow and even elevated fire weather conditions for portions of the western High Plains. The storm was forecast to intensify on Tuesday as moisture quickly advances across the middle and lower Mississippi Valley. Tornadoes and damaging winds were expected.

"Conditions should allow for storms to easily begin rotating, leading to a heightened tornado threat," AccuWeather Meteorologist Andrew Johnson-Levine said. "A couple of strong, long tracked tornadoes also cannot be ruled out."

SEVERE WEATHER LOOMS:Severe weather 'outbreak' to impact South, threatening 25M from Texas to Illinois

New Orleans, Atlanta, Nashville, Birmingham could be impacted

Major metro areas that could experience thunderstorms capable of producing flash flooding and damaging wind gusts on Wednesday include New Orleans, Atlanta, Nashville and Birmingham, Alabama, AccuWeather said.

Airline passengers should expect additional delays north of the thunderstorm zone in the Midwest and the Northeast from Tuesday to Wednesday, AccuWeather said.

Elsewhere, snow could be the problem. Overnight Monday, snow will develop over parts of the North and Central Plains, the National Weather Service said. On Tuesday, snow will develop over the Middle Missouri Valley into the Upper Mississippi Valley. Heavy snow will develop over the parts of the Upper Great Lakes, which has prompted Winter Storm Watches over the region.

Contributing: Thao Nguyen, USA TODAY

search_result.title: Low gas prices mean more Thanksgiving travelers
search_result.text:
John Tuohy

john.tuohy@indystar.com

Holiday travelers, start your engines.

Bolstered by the lowest gas prices in five years, travel industry officials say road trips this Thanksgiving will bump in holiday travel up to 46.3 million people nationwide.

The estimated number of overall travelers is 4.2 percent more than last year and about 90 percent of them will drive at least 50 miles to visit family and friends, according to the AAA Hoosier Motor Club.

In all, about 41.3 million Americans will hit the highways, compared to 38.9 million who drove to Thanksgiving celebrations last year. In Indiana, an estimated 952,000 people will take a road trip, compared to 901,000 last year.

"Certainly, it's safe to say lower gas prices play a role,' said Greg Seiter, a spokesman for the Hoosier AAA. "But Thanksgiving is traditionally a big driving holiday."

The average price for a gallon of regular unleaded gas in Indiana Monday was $2.77 a gallon, the lowest it's been Thanksgiving week since 2009, when it was $2.56 a gallon.

Airlines were expecting a lift in business, too.

More people are expected to fly over the holiday than in any year since 2007 — 3.5 million. At the Indianapolis International Airport 147,000 passengers are expected to pass through the gates between Wednesday and Tuesday.

Amtrak and passenger buses say they expect all their seats to be filled.

Amtrak anticipates topping its record number of 754,000 travelers between Tuesday and Sunday and a company official said every available car will be used, with extra cars added to its busiest routes.

Two routes run through Indianapolis: the Hoosier State, from Indianapolis to Chicago and the Cardinal, from Chicago to New York City.

Greyhound bus service expects 650,000 riders nationwide from Wednesday through Sunday. The company would not disclose — for competitive reasons — the number of riders in Indiana but spokeswoman Lanesha Gipson said routes in an out of Indianapolis will be increased from 31 to 35 on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday.

At Indianapolis' Union Station Tuesday, travelers criss-crossing the country converged as they waited to catch their connecting buses and trains.

Paula Botello, 44, Indianapolis, planned to take a Greyhound bus to Louisville Tuesday morning to visit her boyfriend for a turkey dinner Thanksgiving Day.

"I've never taken the bus, ever, so I don't really know what to expect," said Botello, who paid $81 for the one-way ticket and was sitting on a chair with a single travel bag. "It's comfortable, so far."

Robert Brown, 57, was returning home to Overland Park, Kansas, to be with his family at Christmas after a grueling week attending his 81-year-old father's funeral.

Brown said he took an 11-hour Amtrak trip to Dayton, Ohio, last Tuesday. "It was a very pleasant trip with a cafe car," he said.

He was returning on Greyhound.

"I haven't been on the bus for 40 years," he said. "It's not bad. It's what you make of it. I've met some very nice people."

search_result.title: Thanksgiving travel 2023: How crowded will the Phoenix airport be?
search_result.text:
Expect a side of bustling crowds if you're traveling for your Thanksgiving turkey this year.

With 55.4 million Americans planning to travel 50 miles or more from home this Thanksgiving, AAA thinks the 2023 holiday will have the third-highest travel volumes on record and the highest since the COVID-19 pandemic.

American Airlines forecasted a record number of passengers nationwide for the holiday. The airline, which operates about 40% of flight capacity at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, expects more than 7.8 million passengers nationwide from Nov. 16-28.

United Airlines expects 2023 to be its busiest Thanksgiving ever, and on Nov. 7 it would add more than 1,400 more domestic flights nationwide during Thanksgiving week to meet travel demand.

Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport is preparing for the crush of travelers. Here's what to know if you're flying for Thanksgiving 2023.

Learn more: Best travel insurance

Super Bowl Vegas flights:American increases Phoenix-Las Vegas flights. What they cost

When are the busiest days to fly for Thanksgiving?

Historically, the Sunday after Thanksgiving is the busiest day to fly.

On Nov. 27, 2022, the day after last year's Thanksgiving, Transportation Security Administration screeners processed more than 2.5 million passengers nationwide, making it the busiest travel day of the Thanksgiving holiday.

The days leading up to Thanksgiving are more hectic than usual, too. The TSA screened from 2.1 million to 2.4 million passengers per day from Nov. 17-23, 2022, the seven days before Thanksgiving, data showed. The busiest day to fly was Nov. 23, 2022, with more than 2.4 million passengers.

Is Thanksgiving Day a good day to fly?

Thanksgiving traditionally is the least busy day of the holiday period. The TSA screened more than 1.4 million passengers on Thanksgiving 2022.

Is Phoenix airport very busy?

Sky Harbor does not forecast Thanksgiving weekend traffic in advance, but data from prior years shows November is one of the airport's busiest months because of Thanksgiving.

The airport recorded more than 3.9 million passengers in November 2022, making it the third-busiest month of 2022 and the busiest of the fall season.

How much does it cost to park at Sky Harbor?

Here's how much passengers can expect to pay to park at Sky Harbor Airport for Thanksgiving 2023:

Garages at the terminals cost $30 per day. Premium parking close to the terminal elevators costs $33 per day, while valet parking costs $39 per day.

Three economy garages, one on the airport's west side and two on the east side, charge $16 per day.

Two economy surface lots, one on the east side and one on the west side near the 24th Street PHX Sky Train station, each charge $14 per day. You can ride the free PHX Sky Train to your terminal.

An economy "park and walk" lot that offers no transportation to the terminals is $9 per day.

To make sure you get a spot, reserve your parking ahead of time at www.skyharbor.com.

If you didn't make a reservation, use Sky Harbor's Find a Spot tool, at apps.skyharbor.com/findaspot, before you head to the airport. It will show you parking availability and pricing near your terminal.

Off-site parking is available through companies like PreFlight Airport Parking and the Parking Spot. They offer covered and uncovered parking plus shuttle service to and from the terminals.

PreFlight's rates start at $12.50 per day for an uncovered spot. The Parking Spot's rates vary based on demand and the amount of time on the reservation; The Arizona Republic saw rates for a five-day reservation from Nov. 22-27 start at $28.25 per day for uncovered self-parking.

How to drop off or pick up passengers at Sky Harbor

Sky Harbor Airport roadways and terminal curbs will be busier than usual during the holidays.

One way to avoid traffic jams is to pick up and drop off passengers at one of the airport's two PHX Sky Train Stations instead of driving into the terminals.

There's a Sky Train station on the airport's east side at 44th and Washington streets, and another on the west side at 24th Street and Buckeye Road. The passenger can ride the free Sky Train to the terminals.

If you're picking someone up, wait in one of the free cellphone lots at Sky Harbor instead of driving laps around the terminals.

How early do you need to get to Phoenix airport?

Domestic travelers should allow at least two hours before their flight is scheduled to depart. International travelers should allow at least three hours.

Passengers should check their flight status with their airline before arriving at the airport.

Those looking to get through security fast can consider the airport's free PHX Reserve program, where guests can reserve a place in the TSA line. You can also check security wait times online.

search_result.title: ROAD SAGE: The nightmare of winter holiday travels
search_result.text:
Mike Davis

@byMikeDavis

If you’ve ever planned a road trip during the last week of December, you deserve a medal.

There’s something about getting around during the holidays – from Christmas Eve Eve to New Year’s Day – that makes routine drives seem like the Hunger Games with pretty colors and that one Mariah Carey song.

We all have crazy, weird and annoying travel stories. I once got in a nasty car wreck on Christmas Eve picking up my last present of the season.

But one trip will always stick out: In the winter of 2008, a friend and I drove up to New England to see the Mighty Mighty Bosstones play their annual Christmas shows in Boston and New Year’s Eve show in Providence, R.I. (I was 20. Ska was on a bit of an upswing. Stop laughing at me.)

When we woke up on the morning of Dec. 31 with an hour's drive to Providence ahead, we were met with two inches of snow on the ground.

Gee, we stupidly thought to ourselves, sure glad we aren’t leaving now.

An hour or so later, there was 3 inches of snow on the ground and it wasn’t letting up. We packed as quickly as we could and hit the road.

ROAD SAGE: 'Peak' toll pricing is an absolute joke

I don’t know what your version of “hell” is, but for me, it comes close to a three-hour, 55-mile drive (through an unfamiliar area) during a snowstorm in a Kia that was clearly not designed to handle slush, let alone the kind of snow that gives me heart murmurs (and the kind of snow that New Englanders shrug off as, “Oh, it’s Wednesday”).

If I remember correctly, we only had to dig ourselves out once (on a local road) and skidded out two or three times. I assume that’s what a normal Saturday in the dead of winter is like for New Englanders, anyway.

NCAA president 'very pleased' with revisions to Indiana religious freedom law

Luckily, Mother Nature seems to be in a good mood this winter and a Christmas or New Year’s snowstorm seems to be out of the question, at least in New Jersey. But that only means more cars and everything that comes with them – traffic, crashes and never-ending repeats of that annoying Mariah Carey song.

AAA expects 100.5 million people to travel this year, more than 90 percent by automobile. And it’s nothing new: A study from GasBuddy said that only 19 percent of holiday travelers made new plans due to plummeting gas prices.

And in a shocker to no one: Traffic is the leading cause of holiday stress for about 80 percent of respondents.

ROAD SAGE: Harsh truths for Thanksgiving travelers

Maybe I’m weird (spoiler: I am), but the traffic doesn’t stress me out. It’s a fact of life.

Terrible weather during a trip can make me sweat, but that’s not what I remember when I think about that trip. I can vividly recall the inside jokes, the songs we sang along to and the stupid decision to walk a half-mile from a friend’s apartment to the Middle East concert venue in Allston wearing jeans and a T-shirt.

But that terrible Boston-to-Providence drive? I had to look through old Facebook posts to remember much of it.

It’s a simple formula, folks: Enjoy the holidays and forget how you got there.

Also, if you could cool it with that Mariah Carey song, I’d appreciate it.

search_result.title: Delaware is joining Conference USA as a full member starting in 2025
search_result.text:
NOAH TRISTER

AP

The University of Delaware is joining Conference USA as a full member starting in 2025, the league’s latest expansion with a school moving up from Division I college football’s second tier to the Bowl Subdivision.

The school and league announced the move Tuesday.

“Adding the University of Delaware is a tremendous opportunity for Conference USA as we strategically position ourselves for continued success,” Commissioner Judy MacLeod said in a statement. “We are excited to add the state’s flagship university with its rich history in athletics and academics."

After being raided by the American Athletic Conference and the Sun Belt the past two years, Conference USA re-constituted in 2023 as a nine-team league, including former Championship Subdivision schools Sam Houston State and Jacksonville State.

Delaware has a solid football history, having produced Super Bowl-winning quarterback Joe Flacco and 2002 NFL MVP Rich Gannon. Two-time WNBA MVP Elena Delle Donne played there as well.

“The opportunity to join Conference USA is a very proud moment for our entire university,” athletic director Chrissi Rawak said. “With this step forward, we will continue to offer an incredible student-athlete experience and elevate the visibility of all that is remarkable about UD."

The Blue Hens currently play in the Coastal Athletic Association. The CAA, which changed its name earlier this year from the Colonial Athletic Association, had 15 teams in football this season. The league lost James Madison after the 2021 season, and the Dukes’ transition to the FBS has gone so well they reached the AP Top 25 this year.

UMass, Old Dominion and Georgia State are a few other former CAA programs that now play in the FBS.

Delaware will compete in Conference USA in baseball, men’s and women’s basketball, cross-country, football, men’s and women’s golf, women’s soccer, softball, men’s and women’s tennis, track and field, and volleyball. The school said there would be more information in the months ahead about where its other programs will compete. The Blue Hens reached the NCAA Tournament in men's lacrosse last season and nearly upset top-seeded Duke.

Delaware's most recent FCS football title came in 2003, and it has reached the championship game twice since then. The Blue Hens beat Lafayette last weekend in the FCS playoffs. Coach Ryan Carty's team plays at Montana in the second round this weekend.

Delaware's varsity programs will stay in the CAA through the 2024-25 season, and all of them except football will remain eligible to compete for conference championships and the NCAA postseason. Football is not eligible for a conference title or the FCS playoffs once its transition to the FBS begins after this season.

The school said its 2024 football team will play an FCS schedule. It will be in Conference USA the following year, but won't be eligible to play in the league championship game until 2026.

The football team plays at 22,000-seat Delaware Stadium.

"We are confident that we have the infrastructure in place at UD to compete with the very best in college football and simultaneously witness the growth of our other intercollegiate programs in the department,” Rawak said. “UD Athletics continues to ascend, and Blue Hen football is prepared to take the next step and lead the way.”

FBS football requires extra scholarships, and with gender equity in mind, Delaware said it will be adding another women's varsity sport that will be announced later.

___

AP College Football Writer Ralph D. Russo contributed to this report.
